posts.author: mamabama
posts.content:
Hello experts,

Old time D&D player here, grew up in the world of greyhawk pen and paper.  Got into computer gaming recently and found my way to NwN and WoG persistant world.

Since WoG looked hard I "trained" myself in the game by playing OC, SoTU, HoTu and Sands of Fate, then moved on to Aielund Saga.  Now that Im pretty good at the game in "pause mode" figured i might be ready to try live mode and explore the high difficulty world of greyhawk.

Looked through tons of buiilds here, but have no experience in building, so I wonder if someone might suggest a build to me.  RP wise I want to play an Elf roguey type that is great at traps.  Probably a lot of rogue levels for high SA damage, then become an artful trapper (or avoid areas) where there are lots of undead or SA immune enemies.

Anyway, the combo I was thinking of (and found no builds) was 33rogue, 6monk, 1SD.  Basically a HIPS unarmed melee DEX rogue with IKD for sneak attacks (along with HIPS).  High AC, maybe epic dodge,xtra monk speed, high UMD and trap skills for lots of shadowy shuriken strategy, scrolls etc. Also elf for active search checks. A stealthy monk/rogue would be a fun way to explore a lot of those modules from childhood since you pay attention to details and have to use creative strategy to prevail (especially in SA immune areas).

Im open to other builds too.  Someone said Assassins are improved on WoG so maybe that too.

Thanks for your time!

MamaB

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Greetings and hello MamaB!

I have been playtesting a number of my builds in WoG which goes to 40. 
I started there over 12 months ago
I like the Rogue 33 concept. Lots and lots of sneak attack damage!

I have written a Rogue 33 Monk 6 SD 1 draft, I have only playtested it to level 6.
The Flash
By dropping TWF/Ambi/Improved TW Fighting this would give you three feats to spend on what you wish. 
You can change the race to elf, as 20% multiclass penalties won't matter too much in a persistent world.
With the 6 ability points (+2 dex -2 con from elf, leave dex at 18) one can put Str to 14 and Int up to 10. Or whatever balance you wish.
I also put probably too much HP, 300+ is probably enough. 
(Usually you will want more 16+ monk levels if you want to use fists ie 1d20 fists, otherwise I would consider dual kamas with an elf for lots of attacks)

There are other rogue 33 drafts I have written. The Shadow of Corellion others have enjoyed playing, it is an elf dual shortsword 6-7APR build, I have only playtested that one to 11 but I know Yogmister7 got that one up to level 30 very quickly. Aroveen's Masterful Dagger I haven't had a chance to playtest yet. 

Valerfor who has played WoG extensively in the past made The Sentry of Anduin which is a halfling Rogue 33 Fighter 6 SD 1 build shortsword + shield with +20d6 looks very nice, maybe there are adjustments one can make to make it an elf. 

Torias wrote a Rogue Archer Rogue 33, Fighter 6, SD 1 (+27d6 sneak), very very nice as well.

Hope that gives you some ideas. I think most well designed builds will work fine in WoG, there is some adjustment without pausing of course but one will learn how to manage this with time :) I think amongst this lot there will be a concept you like more than another so definitely keep the conversation going, and as a group the guild members can give you suggestions to get you what you need, as a group the ECB is a veritable gold mine of experience and knowledge.

posts.content:

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Welcome mamabama!

I have levelled the Rogue Archer to level 39.

It is a beast.

One could easily go Elf, but would get an XP penalty.

WoG Assassins got a little boost with Poisons, but BeamDog has nerfed the Death Attack paralyzation to only count on the very first attack (no longer the first flurry as it was before).  Monk stunning fist is also nerfed, being only one round in duration (BeamDog nerf).

Shadow Dancers got a bigger boost on WoG, with some of the abilities (summons, shadow evade, etc) being boosted.  HiPS, however, is on a timer.

Learning to play without the pause bar is a big step up.  You may feel overwhelmed at times.  Just keep in mind that many of us oldies do it, and in time it will come as if it is natural.  Clever use of both the hotbars and the F keys are very helpful in managing actions, items, spells, etc.

WoG for first timers is very, very hard.  It has a very steep learning curve.  You will dirtnap often.  It is a PW that was made for Party play, so soloing it is very difficult, even for expert Players.

My advice - go slow, don't get discouraged, and ask for help if stuck, etc. You will find that most Players on WoG are very helpful.  We have all been where you are now.  I can tell you now, as an old time D&D Player and DM, the Greyhawk PnP converted modules on WoG are first class - among the best conversions I have played.

From Hommlet, to the Temple of Elemental Evil, the Giant series, Drow, Queen of the Demonweb Pits, and many, many more, all are well done conversions.  I kind of envy you due to all the wonderful things you are going to be discovering and enjoying.  NWN brings a unique experience to the D&D world imo.  Reliving those old PnP modules in the NWN format has been for me an incredible and wonderous journey.  The new additions of the Saltmarsh U series is just awesome sauce.

I think you will do well to start with a Rogue based Character with HiPS and good speed.  As an Elf, it should do very well as WoG does have lots of traps, secret doors, and other surprises that keen senses will be helpful against.  Sneaking is a viable tactic on WoG, with only a few creatures and bosses having vanilla True Sight.  The HiPS timer is annoying, but acceptable at 6 seconds.  You should be aware that there are rarely any convo stat, skill or feat checks on the PW.  So investing in Persuasion, etc will just be a waste of skill points, and you will want to put those very valuable skill points in other, more useful skills (UMD, Tumble, Hide, Move Silently, Concentration (due to Taunt), Discipline (to avoid being Disarmed), Open Locks, Disarm Traps, Craft Traps, Set Traps.  Note that Appraise is used at Merchants.  Also, just about every creature and their mamas sneak, so you will need Listen and/or Spot, as well as Search.

Yes, the skill points will be spent before one gets them.  One can never have enough skill points on WoG!

I personally would suggest starting in Hommlet - it is the easiest route imo and is also one of the most memorable.  I would suggest purchasing a Horse at first - Horses grant more speed and can be used to kite opponents with ranged weapons (though without Mounted Combat there will be a minus to hit with ranged).  Later you will be able to pick up Boots of Travel and dispose of the Horse,  if you are so inclined.

Enjoy!

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Hey mamabama!
Web has written some great stuff, I might read a bit of it myself :)
RE attacks per round (APR) you are correct, nice one! :)
Skill mastery I wouldn't bother with, set the traps with take 20 outside of combat, in combat I would focus on killing them with the crazy attacks per round, buffed with UMD and sneak attack and HiPS and lure them into traps. With HiPS you have an incredible strategic advantage as long as the enemy doesnt have real true seeing (ie a Dragon). Its nice but probably not quite as strong as other options
HiPS has a timer of 6 seconds I believe in WoG. In vanilla NWN HiPS has unlimited uses / round. NPC enemies only check stealth once every 6 seconds. So how OP is that :) 
Oh and strength is handy to have. I find myself regretting not putting Str to 14 on most of my rogue builds. (non rogues too). One can find ways to buff it up for non-sneak damage, and it helps for sure carrying mountains of loot across the vast plains of WoG. Not everything will be vulnerable to sneak attacks (ie Dragons, Undead, Constructs), so the extra Str is good, but for those who are vulnerable, they will not survive very long against a Rogue 33 build.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
WoG uses CEP Weapons, which includes asian weapons like the waki, sai, goads, wind firewheels, etc.

Most also have all the weapon feats as well as WM WoC.

As for Epic Traps - I am not sure if the system for making them is implemented on WoG. I know it was discussed.

I have never attempted to make Traps on WoG as there are more than enough to Recover, and one can purchase them at specialty shops. YMMV.

To Disarm, one is going to need a modified level of 68 to Recover Epic Traps (which is what I do). Since there are lots of ways to boost Set Trap, I think 25 ranks will be enough with Take 20 to set them.

Sent from my SM-G955F using Tapatalk

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Kamas I think you will be disappointed with the range. There are some ok late pre-epic kamas but I cannot recall a single epic kama.
Shortswords on the other hand, you will be very happy with. There are great epic shortswords that drop. 
There are Wakizashis for sale but not a lot of enchanted ones.
I cannot comment on looks as I haven't really modified them. With flame weapon (or bless weapon, great against undead with an amazing duration from scrolls) on them, it is hard to see the weapon sometimes :)

This is Dianne (Mistress of Mayaheine), I have playtested to about level 27. 
Dual shortswords with flame weapon applied. Modified robes to have a metallic exterior. 

Set trap 45 modified should be enough to set epic traps with take 20, at least according to the NWN wiki, the DC to set the epic traps should be 65. 
Disable trap I usually put up as high as possible but I note Web has the numbers on how much is needed to recover. 
Craft trap you can invest in, however the best traps one can craft are deadly traps. I'd only invest a few points at most, and try to look for items to boost your craft trap skills. I have been able to craft deadly electrical traps with no ranks in craft trap, but with lots of int and +craft traps boosts. Reagents can be tricky to obtain to make deadly traps, 7 / trap is significant, retrieving em is likely going to be your priority, I think. Making a handful of low level traps early game is very very powerful. With a decent low level trap field (ie minor ele/fire traps), bosses can be taken down early game much easier, as long as they dont have evasion! I think it is worth making minor traps early game. I find once my sneak attack damage is nice and high, plus I get equipment / UMD / sequencers, I dont have to rely so much on traps as I used to, which is a good thing, evasion is a pretty nasty counter to trap damage output.

posts.author: mamabama
posts.content:
Thanks Stagmeister, very helpful link!

From HipMaestro's guide the numbers are

DETECT epic traps, rogue only
Eventual: 43 - 20 = 23
Immediate: 43 - 1 = 42

RECOVER traps, epic, all classes
58 + 10 - 20 = 48 (46 w/synergy); XCL, only w/foci & modified INT >/= 34 (See Note 4)

SET epic traps
65 - 20 = 45 (43 w/synergy); XCL, only w/foci & modified DEX >/= 28

Though WebShaman notes above there are alot of ways to boost set traps, so 25 will do for that.

Thank you all again for the good advice.  See you in game!

posts.author: Asturonethoriusaline
posts.content:
Another Idea is:

1. Ranger 9/Rogue 30/SD 1

2. Bard 5 to 8 to 11/Rogue 28 to 31 to 34

3. Monk 1/Ranger 9/Rogue 30

4. Druid 25/Rogue 14/SD 1

What these build splits do that the others do is offer you something in addition to sneak attacking, while still being a good Sneak Attacker.

The Ranger/Rog/SD gives you higher AB, improved 2 weapon fighting, and a Animal Companion(Animal companions are buffed, better in WOG then other PW's), and Spells, favored enemy..

The Bard/Rog/SD, gives you synergy, bard song, buff Spells

Monk 1/Ranger 9/Rog 30 gives you a HELL OF A LOT of attacks per round, to go with sneak attacking(about 7,8,9,10 attacks per round with Flurry + Improved 2 weapon fighting + haste), animal companion, spells, favored enemy.

In these builds your only giving up 2,3,4,5 rogue levels, and taking 28,29,30,31 levels of Rogue, instead of 33, but what your getting makes that a great tradeoff.

Race: Either Elf or Halfling(Elf gives you Bow and access to Rapier or Longsword.

Stats:

Str 10 to 12 to 14(14 at extreme highest)(10 at extreme lowest)

Dex: 17

Con 10 to 12 to 14(10 at lowest, 14 at highest, 12 at highest.

Wis 12 to 14 to 16(12 at lowest, 14 at average, 16 if Monk, and if Str is 10/12, Dex is 17,18, con is 10/12, int 13/14

Int 14.

Cha 8/10.

Feats: If taking SD: Dodge/Mobility either to start/ an or 3rd level,an or 6th level,an or 9th level

If no SD like in Monk 1/6/Ranger 9/Rogue 25/30, then:

1. Expertise,

3rd. Weapon Finesse(Can use a Rapier(18 to 20 crit, see improved crit rapier below), with Weapon Finesse, and use Dexterity Bonus for Both AB(Attack Bonus and AC)

6th. Weapon Focus Rapier

9th: Blind Fight, Point Blank Shot, Extend Spell(if take spell caster), Knockdown(If not going to take 6 levels of Monk to get IKD

12: Improved Crit Rapier(A epic Keen Rapier(18 to 20 Crit, then 16 to 20 Keen, then 14 to 20 epic Keen), plus improved crit(16 to 20 on a normal rapier, 14 to 20 on a keen Rapier, 12 to 20 on a epic Keen Rapier.

15: Improved Knockdown if dont take 6 levels of Monk, otherwise either Improved Expertise, Blindfight if didnt take earlier, Extend Spell,

Epic Feats: Epic Dodge, Armor Skin, Epic Weapon Focus Rapier, Epic Prowess, Great Dex's, Fast Movement(Haste your character without using spell)

These class level splits, plus these stats, plus these feats, plus weapon finesse, improved 2 weapon dual wielding 2 rapiers one in each hand or 2 Kama's.

Lets you:

Do other things besides sneak atracking.

And when you sneak attack:

Your going to attack a LOT, sneak attack a LOT.

Do a LOT of Sneak Attack Damage.

Crit a lot.

Do a lot of Crit Damage.

As far as Skills.

37 to 47in:

Hide

Move Silently

Disable Trap.

UMD

Tumble.

Search

26 to 36 in

Listen or Spot(But not both, choose 1 or the other.)

Discipline

Concentration(If playing a Ranger/Rogue

Bard/Rogue

Druid/Rogue

17 to 25

Perform(if a Bard/Rogue)

You might be tempted to take a 16 int for more skill points.

14 is enough since Rangers, Monks, Bards, that multi class with Rogue, and since Rogue get a LOT of Skill points.

If want, need more skill points then a 14 int, stay with 14 int, and play a Human multiclassed rogue.

If take a 16 int, your not going to have enough for a:

Str 10,12,14

Dex 17,18

Con 10,12

Int 14

Wis 12,14,16

Cha 8,10

Also make sure u have a minimum of 13/14 in INT, for both Skill Points and to take Expertise, Knockdown, IKD(if dont take 6 levels of Monk)

Also dont overlook point blank shot, ranged, at least early to mid levels.

Shooting enemies, pulling 1,2 enemies to you, where can finish them off with either melee or sneak attack or ranged, is better then fighting 7 to 100 enemies all at once.

Others can fine tune what I gave said for you a lot better then I can.

But these general multiclass splits, stats, feats, etc, are pretty good.

Now whether these suggestions are what your looking for, I dont know.

But hey just throwing the ideas out there for you.
